Situation1: They have a serious conversation about financial or health decisions that require full transparency and mutual understanding.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone pressed to my ear, my husband across from me with a stack of medical bills between us. He wanted to talk—really talk—about our finances, about his recent diagnosis, about what we were going to do next. He needed me to be honest, to share my fears and hopes, to be his partner. But just as he started to open up, my work phone buzzed. It was a long-time customer, furious about a recent offer, demanding answers, threatening to cancel. My manager expected me to handle objections calmly, to keep the customer satisfied, to protect the company’s reputation. My husband’s eyes searched mine for reassurance, for openness, while the customer’s voice grew louder in my ear, insisting on explanations. I felt pulled in two directions—one demanding my heart, the other my professionalism. My hands shook as I tried to decide which voice to answer first, knowing that whichever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
